content.text: is a system to generate user facing documentation from markup files (markdown only at the moment).
Documentation files seat next to your product codebase and are part of your product's SDLC.
provides directives to simplify your day-to-day documentation process as well as to improve maintenance in a long run.
Continue reading to learn more about
leveraging existing code snippets and test results
If you are reading this documentation for the first time, I suggest to read in the intended order
(there is a next button at the bottom of each page).
Feel free to use Table Of Contents on the left, or search (top right) otherwise.
Keeping documentation up-to-date is a hard task.
The further documentation is from the code the more likely it won't be updated when a feature is added or changed.
Depending on your product and clients, stale documentation effects are:
As part of your code review you check that there are:
Now it is time to add to it
Even non functional changes may require documentation update.
Here are some activities that most likely put your documentation out of sync:
Our code base already contains a wast amount of data.
Instead of copy-and-paste we leverage artifacts around us.
examples of how to use API (part of code)
Markup based documentation is widely used as well
There is a cost to maintain them.
Instead of building separate slides and keep them up-to-date,
this system automatically generates slides from your documentation content.
Markdown uses ASCII to represent styles and page structure.
Example of how to keep your documentation up-to-date by referencing existing resource.
extension and is not part of a standard markdown syntax.

to add the command line to your hosts.
to make sure tool is available.
to create a minimum set of files for your documentation.

Open prompted url inside your browser.
icon in the top right corner indicates that preview is on.
Open any text editor, modify and save
Changes will be displayed in the browser.

```tabs
JavaScript: :include-file: file-name.js
Java: :include-file: wide-code.java
Cpp: :include-cpp: simple.cpp {entry: 'main', bodyOnly: true}
```

tokens.content:
```tabs
JavaScript: 
First you need to download WebStorm and then run following using your terminal

    $ yarn install
    $ yarn start
    
Java: 
First you need to download Intellij IDEA and then run following using your terminal
    
    $ mvn install
    $ mvn exec:exec
    
Cpp: 
First you need to download CLion and then run following using your terminal

    $ pwd
    $ whoamis
```

Define templates when you need to repeat the same layout more than once.
Instead define a template in a separate file.
Insert it using fenced block syntax. Content inside of fenced block is treated as key/values.

tokens.content:
```template templates/job.md
name: Sathish
title: Software Engineer
```

content.text: Consider inlined template if you don't need to pass a lot of text as parameters to the template

tokens.content:
:include-template: templates/arg-definition.md {name: "Arg Name", description: "Description of the argument"}

:include-template: templates/arg-definition.md {name: "Other Name", optional: true, description: "Yet another description of the argument"}

NGINX stores every access to access.log. It kerberizes the request.
Log Stash runs on the same machine and consumes access.log lines.
As long as lines contain required information it gets processed.
Log stash won't write data directly to Elastic. Instead we will use Kafka as a buffer in front.
Another instance of Log Stash consumes records from Kafka queue and writes them to Elastic.
Need follow-up with ELK team to see if buffer is still required.
Finally data gets written to Elastic by LogStash. Access.log timestamp will be the primary timestamp of a record.
We have built a web app to display news consumption analytics. And URL is be accessible by everyone.
Most of the data we take from Elastic. Data grows very fast and we need to come up with a scalable approach.
CMDB departments, active users and potential other information we take from CMDB. We can't replicate this queries by simply using
out of the box Kibana interface
